prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Reasonableness of Restrictive Covenants—Scope of Activity

para.paratext: As to the scope of activity restrained, a covenant should be as specific as possible, i.e., related to certain identifiable activities and information.[1] In coming to a conclusion, the courts will also look to the specific and general intentions of the parties. In Capital Safe & Lock Service Ltd. v. Steeves,[2] the court held:

When ambiguous language is employed to identify the activity that a non-competition covenant is supposed to prohibit, courts will not hesitate to look beyond the covenant itself to ascertain the true intention of the parties … Such a contextual examination necessarily involves the preambles to any non-competition covenant. See Baird v. Jones (1919), 47 N.B.R. 31 (S.C.) and Gibson v. Campbell (1922), 49 N.B.R. 185 (S.C.). The context in which Mr. Steeves' non-competition covenant was formulated elucidates the nature of the competition that it prohibits.

The courts will also look to the circumstances of the individual situation. In Yellowhead Petroleum Products Ltd. v. United Farmers of Alberta Co-Operative Ltd.,[3] the court cited the Supreme Court of Canada's decision in Hecke v. Compagnie de Gestion Maskoutaine Ltee,[4] finding that:

… the restraint on woodworking would not have been upheld because it would have prohibited Hecke from working at the general store which sells toothpicks. It is not reasonable, realistic or possible to require that parties identify all exceptions to a restraint on the basis that one might theoretically attempt to apply the restriction in such a manner. In any event, UFA is not asserting that the clause would cover the hypothetical situations suggested in para. 39. It is simply asserting that the restriction covers the impugned activities, which are clearly prohibited and reasonably so.

In my view, the challenge to the enforceability of the non-competition covenant founded on its alleged overbreadth is without merit. Whether a non-competition covenant is overly broad depends on the particular circumstances of each case as they existed at the time that the covenant was given and any decision on that question is largely fact-driven. For Yellowhead to attempt to have the clause declared unenforceable based on types of business Bradley and Hornland never contemplated engaging in, to my mind goes against the equities of the situation and is unhelpful. Were the Court inclined to the view that the clause was overly broad the “notional severance” technique as discussed by the Supreme Court of Canada in Transport North American Express Inc. v. New Solutions Financial Corp., [2004] 1 S.C.R. 249 (S.C.C.) might possibly be applicable.

The defendants in 2261897 Ontario Inc. v. Quest Audio Visual Inc.[5] moved for summary judgment on the claim and counterclaim arising from the departure of the defendant Terry from his former employment at the plaintiff Center Stage. Terry had worked in the Audio Visual industry for a number of years and in association with a number of different employers. His expertise was in the field of sales and, over the years, he had developed a “stable” of clients with whom he had a close relationship and who followed him through the various changes in his employment status over several years. Terry's various employers were in the business of assisting their clients to stage multi-media events such as conferences, presentations and the like, at venues both public and private across the country. While clients in this industry might return repeatedly to a single supplier or relationship, contracts were almost invariably restricted to a single event or project. In August, 2011, Terry left his prior employer and accepted a position as “Senior Account Executive/Director of Business Development” at the plaintiff Center Stage and signed a contract of employment. A significant element in his hire was his ability to bring with him a “book of business” represented by his existing client contacts and his ability to lever his relationship with them and familiarity with their business needs to obtain new business over time. The plaintiff was keen to ensure that Terry entered all data from his contacts and events that he worked on with them into their proprietary data base so future use could be made of it. Terry was not paid anything for the relationships he brought with him and the plaintiff sought no assurances regarding Terry's possible status as a fiduciary from his former employer beyond verifying that there was no non-solicitation agreement in place. Terry's contract of employment contained a non-solicitation clause. For just over two years, from August, 2011 until November 7, 2013, Terry worked with the plaintiff. In October, 2013, a major contract obtained by Terry for the plaintiff with the Bank of Nova Scotia experienced technical difficulties. The client was unhappy and sought certain discounts or credits from the plaintiff. In the course of an exchange of emails regarding the matter of the requested discount, a principal of the plaintiff, sent a number of intemperate emails to Terry which virtually dared him to resign. On November 5, 2013, that principal of the plaintiff and Terry had another unpleasant confrontation. On November 7, 2013, Terry wrote to the plaintiff indicating that he was resigning with immediate effect. The next day, Terry commenced work with the defendant Quest under a contract of employment that on its terms was economically superior to the one Terry had with the plaintiff. Quest obtained a number of contracts after Terry joined them from six former clients of the plaintiff. In no case was there evidence of solicitation of any of these clients by Terry. They were, for the most part, long time contacts of Terry brought with him from when he joined the plaintiff in 2011 or, in one case, a client that a long-time client had recommended him to and who took the initiative of searching out Terry's new employer.[6]

The court concluded that the plaintiff had no claim for breach of non-solicitation provisions of the Non-Solicitation provisions of the Employment Agreement against either defendant. As drafted, the non-solicitation agreement would potentially prohibit Terry from earning any kind of living in the industry for a year and was manifestly unreasonable. Neither Terry nor a prospective employer would have any basis to know which potential client was included or excluded. A blanket prohibition on dealing with a broad, unknown data base of actual and former customers and clients or prospects of the plaintiff unrelated to actual confidential information pertaining to such customers possessed by the party being restrained is overbroad.[7]

The plaintiff alleged that Terry was bound by the full range of fiduciary duties which, they claimed, included non-solicitation obligations. The judge was of the view that there was no issue requiring a trial on the matter of whether Terry was a fiduciary. The trial judge noted as follows:

D. Brown J., as he then was, conducted a detailed review of the jurisprudence regarding fiduciary duties of departing employees and which types of employees have and have not been found to be subject to fiduciary duties in the case of Boehmer Box L.P. v Ellis Packaging Limited et al., [2007] O.J. No. 1694. Factors which he found to be important in that case included exclusive relationships with customers, the ability to act unilaterally and bind the employer as well as the responsibility of supervising employees. The employee in question in Boehmer was the highest paid employee of the plaintiff, a factor which failed to weigh heavily since the compensation came largely from commissions. The employee was found not to be a fiduciary but rather someone who “seemed to perform the classic roles of a good salesperson --- know where the market is, and keep the customer satisfied”. I find the phrase a particularly apt description of Mr. Terry's role in the present case.[8]

The judge concluded that Terry was not a fiduciary. Terry had no exclusive territory or customers per se. Far from being management, he was treated and described by a principal of the plaintiff rather derisively as an employee who had failed to make transition to earn promotion into management. While he certainly bid for contracts from clients and, to that extent, might be said to have “set prices”, he only “set prices” in the way that an estimator on a construction project sets prices. His budgets, invoices and write-downs were subject to review, supervision and approval procedures from above. Expenses on sales calls needed to be pre-approved by his supervisors. He was closely supervised, admonished and disciplined on numerous occasions by a principal of the plaintiff. The judge concluded that all of the foregoing was inconsistent with a fiduciary and the very limited evidence of a nominal supervisory role over two other sales people did not alter the picture.[9]

The plaintiff characterized Terry as the “face” of Center Stage with its clients. The judge concluded that the employment agreement and the evidence told a different tale. The employment agreement obliged him to enter details regarding events “to allow Operations to implement the job”. The evidence was that Terry was not required to be on site for events that he sold as the technical team of the plaintiff were used for that purpose. The plaintiff had a number of faces working with clients on events --- Terry was merely the “sales” face for clients he brought to the plaintiff.[10]

The judge observed that the claim that the defendant was a fiduciary precluded from maintaining any relationship with clients that he brought at no charge to the plaintiff was all the more untenable when coupled with the conclusion that the plaintiff repudiated its agreement with Terry and constructively dismissed him. This fact took Terry's fact situation out of the fact pattern of all of the cases cited by the plaintiff which involved employees who secretly competed for several years with their employer or who exploited exclusive relationships granted to them by their employer and developed during their employment. As a non-fiduciary, Terry's obligations as a departing employee were not extensive and there was no evidence that any of these were breached. There was no evidence that he took any actual confidential information of any kind with him.[11]

The judge noted that the duties of a departing fiduciary are not fixed and uniform. Misuse of confidential information to the detriment of its rightful owner, for example, is a frequently cited basis for intervention by the courts. The problem with the plaintiff's claim was that substantially all of the client relationships that it sought to impose an exclusive protective cloak around via its equitable claims were relationships that the plaintiff had prior to allegedly becoming a fiduciary. This was not a case of sale of a business --- the plaintiff did not buy the goodwill from Terry. He did not possess any confidential information from them since he already possessed it before becoming associated with them. A fiduciary, particularly one whose employment has been terminated, would not have more than the slightest of duties to the employer. Such duties might, for example, extend to a brief period of non-solicitation that might not preclude responding to contacts initiated by the client, and certainly not in cases where there is any suggestion the employer is using the window to defame the former employee. The parties entered into an agreement regarding non-solicitation which by its terms was inapplicable. The court should not impose through fiduciary duties stricter limitations than the parties themselves have bargained for in their contract.[12]

If mistaken in characterizing Terry as a non-fiduciary, the court would have nevertheless dismissed the plaintiff's claims on the basis that the right to call a fiduciary to account is of course a prerogative of the courts of equity and equity has ever required clean hands of its applicants. An employer who constructively dismisses an employee, viciously defamed him both to his new employer and to at least one client while making thinly veiled threats to the new employer is in no position to claim clean hands when it approaches a court of equity for relief in respect of a client list it acquired from that same employee free of charge.[13]

In 2909731 Canada Inc. v. Toews,[14] the plaintiff sought by way of summary trial to enjoin its former employees, Toews and Tobber from operating Tobra or any competing business and soliciting customers of the plaintiff for a period of 24 months from the date that each of Toews and Tobra left the plaintiff's employ. The plaintiff also sought to enjoin Toews and Tobber from using any confidential information belonging to the plaintiff, including customer lists and addresses of customers.[15]

The plaintiff had since 1997 carried on the business of designing, manufacturing and selling customized promotional products. Ninety percent of its trade consisted of sales to businesses in the automotive industry. Over the course of its 18 years in business, the plaintiff created what a “Master Contact List”, which contained the names and contact information of approximately 8,000 people at various organizations throughout North America, most of which were automobile dealerships. According to the plaintiff, the Master Contact List was compiled from information that was not publicly available and thousands of man hours were required to create it.[16]

In April 2009, Toews began working for the plaintiff as a sales account manager. She was assigned approximately 800 of the contacts on the Master Contact List. The employment agreement Toews signed when she commenced her employment included a confidentiality clause. On April 27, 2009, Toews signed a confidentiality agreement. On March 23, 2012, Toews further signed an Employee Confidentiality/Conflict of Interest Agreement which was significantly more comprehensive than the April 27, 2009 agreement. In 2013, Toews was promoted to the position of sales coordinator. Her duties included overseeing approximately 10 sales managers. She was given access to the entire Master Contact List. In June 2015, Toews decided to relinquish her sales coordinator position and she returned to her previous job as a sales account manager.[17]

In February 2009, Tobber began working for the plaintiff as a shipping assistant. He signed an employment contract, confidentiality agreement and Employee Confidentiality/Conflict of Interest Agreement containing the same confidentiality terms as were contained in the Toews's contracts. During the course of his employment, Tobber was promoted to Operations Manager. His responsibilities included managing the shipping department and reviewing product orders.[18]

On January 26, 2015, unbeknownst to the plaintiff and while they were still employed by the plaintiff, Toews and Tobber formally registered Tobra as a business partnership. In September 2015, Toews and Tobber began operating Tobra. Their website, www.tobra.ca, uses a similar design and colour scheme to that used by the plaintiff's website. It advertised for sale the same types of customized promotional merchandise offered for sale by the plaintiff. However, unlike the plaintiff, the defendants' business was not focused on the sale of those products to the automotive industry.[19]

The sale of promotional products to the automobile and other industries is a highly competitive business. There are dozens of entities in Canada that are engaged in the business. The summary trial judge concluded that there is nothing unique about sourcing and selling promotional products. The skills required and utilized for the job of sales and shipping are neither unique nor specialized. Importantly, there was no evidence that the plaintiff had any form of exclusive arrangement with any of its customers. The products it sold were freely available from manufacturers. There was no evidence of any particular customer loyalty towards the plaintiff. Each customer was more interested in maximizing its financial advantage over the vendor than it was in allegiance to the plaintiff. Each was “fair game” for any competitor.[20]

The summary trial judge concluded that neither Toews nor Tobber owed a fiduciary duty to the plaintiff. Although Toews and Tobber may have had a modicum of discretionary authority in their respective areas of employment, neither of them was conferred with any significant authority that affected the plaintiff's legal or practical interests. Neither was involved in the decision-making process that affected the plaintiff's ongoing business in a significant way. Neither had the power to hire or fire, neither was a corporate officer or director, and both of them required the approval of Duquesne for any significant expenditure or decision related to the business. It was Mr. Duquesne who supervised the plaintiff's employees, including Toews and Tobber, and wielded power and control over them and over the plaintiff's business. Duquesne alone was the ultimate decision-maker regarding products and pricing. Nothing Toews and Tobber did in their respective employment positions resulted in the plaintiff being vulnerable to, or at their mercy. Although both were eager and competent employees, they occupied relatively minor positions in the plaintiff's hierarchy.[21]

There was no evidence that either of Toews or Tobber used information from the Master Contact List as a “springboard” or head start for their business. What occurred was nothing other than what generally occurs whenever an employee leaves an employer and uses the experience gained during that employment to start a business. The plaintiff failed to demonstrate that either Toews or Tobber breached a duty of confidence owed to the plaintiff.[22]

There was no evidence that either Toews or Tobber disclosed any Confidential Information to any other person or legal entity. Moreover, there was no evidence that either of them used any Confidential Information for his or her own purposes. Although the defendants sold competitive products to one customer and one prospective customer of the plaintiff, there was no evidence that any Confidential Information as defined by the Employee Confidentiality/Conflict of Interest Agreement was used for those sales or that either of Toews or Tobber solicited either entity to make the sale. The plaintiff failed to point to any evidence that Toews and Tobber were in breach of the provisions of their respective confidentiality clauses. In essence, the plaintiff's position was akin to submitting that merely competing in business was sufficient. An employer is not entitled to be protected from competition at the hands of a former employee merely on the basis of the former employment alone.[23]

The restrictive covenant provision was broad and sweeping. It sought to prohibit Toews from competing with the plaintiff “in a similar field” anywhere. There was no geographic limitation. Clearly, Toews began to compete with the plaintiff in the sale of customized promotional products within the 12 month restricted period. The question was whether she was contractually prohibited from doing so by an enforceable restrictive covenant. In order for a determination to be made as to whether or not a restrictive covenant is reasonable, the covenant must be unambiguous. The onus is on the party seeking to enforce the restrictive covenant to show the reasonableness of its terms. An ambiguous restrictive covenant will be prima facie unenforceable because the party seeking to enforce it will be unable to demonstrate reasonableness in the face of an ambiguity. The restrictive covenant was unenforceable. First, it was ambiguous. There was no definition of “similar field”. Second, the plaintiff did not have a proprietary interest that was entitled to protection. There was nothing about its business that was unique or specialized. Its “Master Contact List” was nothing more than a compilation of names and contact information of 8,000 of the approximately 20,000 automobile dealerships in North America, 2,000 of which dealerships had purchased from the plaintiff within the last seven years. The information was readily available in the public domain. Due to the proliferation of and ease with which information is available on the internet, the summary trial judge questioned the relevance of the decisions of courts pre-dating the internet that had generally found contact lists, without more, to qualify as confidential. Third, there were no spatial or geographic limitations to the restrictive covenant clause. It purported to restrict Toews from competing with the plaintiff or working in a similar field anywhere in the world for 12 months. Finally, the restrictive covenant was not limited to prohibiting solicitations of the plaintiff's customers. It was all encompassing. Non-competition clauses are enforceable only in exceptional circumstances. There were no exceptional circumstances here. The restrictive covenant was unreasonable and was therefore, unenforceable.[24]

The courts will not prevent a former employee from competing for customers that were not serious potential customers of the former employer. Likewise, where the geographical area covered is large, the employer will be required to establish that a broad restraint is necessary in the circumstances, such as where the employee had direct contact with and information relating to specific customers over the entire area.[25] An employee will not normally be restrained from competing in areas in which he or she had no personal connections or involvement during the course of employment.[26]

In Craig v. CEO Global Network Inc.,[27] CEO Global was in the business of providing professional consulting services to corporate executives through group mentoring, expert speaker programs and executive coaching. Wilson carried on that business previously with a competitor, TEC Canada, where he worked with the Plaintiff Craig. After Wilson established CEO Global, he invited Craig to join. Craig became the executive vice-president of CEO Global. The Consulting Agreement he signed provided for a one-year term that would automatically renew on its anniversary date subject to rights of early termination. Part way through the second term, CEO Global provided sixty days' notice to Craig of termination of the Consulting Agreement. CEO Global agreed to pay Craig six months' compensation additional to the sixty days' notice, consistent with its interpretation of the Consulting Agreement's provision for termination without cause. CEO Global paid Craig the first month of notice, but then did not pay the second month of notice or the six months of additional compensation. CEO Global's lawyer notified Craig that CEO Global was discharged from making any further payments to him because it discovered that he had breached the non-competition provision contained in the Consulting Agreement, thereby entitling CEO Global it to terminate the Consulting Agreement for cause.[28]

On March 29, 2019, Craig produced to CEO Global a confidential client and prospective client list that he had downloaded from the CEO Global computer system four days after he was provided with notice of termination but before the expiry of the sixty-day notice period. He also produced a copy of CEO Global's Strategic Plan created on February 4, 2011 that he had retained. At the start of the closing submissions at trial, CEO Global amended its statement of defence to plead that it was entitled to terminate the Consulting Agreement with cause by reason of Craig's breach of the confidentiality provision of the Consulting Agreement and his breach of the duty of honesty and good faith that he owed to CEO Global in the performance of the contract. CEO Global did not tender any evidence of any harm, or detriment of any nature, resulting from Craig having had confidential documents in his possession in the more than seven years that had passed since termination. The trial judge concluded that CEO Global failed to establish just cause for its termination of the Consulting Agreement. The Plaintiff was entitled to judgment against CEO Global of $150,899, plus pre-judgment interest.[29]

CEO Global contended that it was justified in terminating Craig for cause on the basis that he materially breached the Non-Competition Provision. The burden of establishing that the Non-Competition Provision is lawful and enforceable is on the party seeking its enforcement. The general principle applied in most common law jurisdictions is that “non-competition clauses in employment contracts are void” because a non-competition provision in an employment contract is a restraint of trade, and restraints of trade are contrary to public policy considerations because they interfere with individual liberty of action. The Supreme Court has stated that restrictive covenants are enforceable only when they are reasonable. The onus is on the party seeking to enforce the restrictive covenant to establish that its terms are reasonable. The Supreme Court of Canada has drawn a distinction between restrictive covenants contained in commercial contracts and in contracts pertaining to employment, noting that different considerations are pertinent to each. In particular, in the employment setting there may be an imbalance in power between the parties to the employment contract. The reasonableness test for assessment of a restrictive covenant has been found to be applicable to independent contractor relationships as to employer-employee relationships.[30]

An ambiguous restrictive covenant is prima facie unreasonable. The ambiguity in the Non-Competition Provision was its prohibition that Craig could not engage in or carry on a “business similar to the business” carried on by CEO Global. This presented an ambiguity in the scope of the Non-Competition Provision that was made obvious by the disproportionate amount of trial time expended in debate concerning whether Craig's provision of one-on-one executive coaching was a “business similar” to that conducted by CEO Global. The “use of the words ‘or a business similar thereto’ introduces a massive breadth of possible interpretations and hence introduces great uncertainty and ambiguity into the clause”. The business of CEO Global in providing professional consulting services to corporate executives was already broad in scope, and the use of the term “business similar” broadened the provision so vastly that it became ambiguous and could not be reasonable.[31]

On the other hand, the courts have upheld general restraints on competition where a former employee had significant ties to and knowledge concerning the employer's customers.[32] For example, in Elsley v. J.G. Collins Insurance Agencies Ltd.,[33] the Supreme Court of Canada held as follows:
… Elsley dealt with the customers of the agency to the almost total exclusion of Collins [the owner]. To them Elsley was the business, Collins little more than a name.

He had knowledge of the insurable assets, financial credit, likes and dislikes and idiosyncrasies of each customer, in a recurring and confidential relationship not unlike that of lawyer/client or doctor/patient. It was only natural that policy-holders would follow him if he made a change.

In Elsley, the information and position of the former employee were such that he had “acquired a close personal acquaintance” with customers and would likely have “appropriated” the business of his former employer.[34]

The courts have also upheld covenants in circumstances where a defendant was in clear breach of an agreement and had received consideration.[35] As to whether continued employment constitutes adequate consideration, the decisions are inconsistent and must be analyzed carefully.[36] Globex Foreign Exchange Corp. v. Kelcher[37] summarized the conflicting case law as follows:

The appellants argue that continued employment alone does not constitute consideration for amendments to an employment relationship. Some additional benefit must flow to the employee. We were referred to two different lines of cases: Maguire and Techform, in which consideration was found, and Francis v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (1994), 120 D.L.R. (4th) 393, 21 O.R. (3d) 75 (C.A.), and Hobbs v. TDI Canada Ltd. (2004), 246 D.L.R. (4th) 43 (Ont. C.A.), in which it was not. The chambers judge found that the facts in this case were more akin to those in Maguire and Techform.

The employment contract at issue in Maguire provided for one month's notice of termination. Some 11 months after the commencement of employment, the employee executed a covenant that he would not compete with the employer for a period of five years after his employment ceased. He continued to work for the company for another three years, at which time he was dismissed. The Supreme Court of Canada found that there was ample consideration for the bond, stating that the evidence established two things: (1) “that the employee was given to understand, and did understand, that his refusal to execute the covenant would lead to an early termination of his employment”, and (2) “that the employer tacitly promised that if the bond were signed, the employment would not soon be terminated”. After the covenant was entered into the “employer refrained indefinitely from exercising its legal right to issue the notice which, at the expiration of one month, would terminate the employment”.

The Ontario Court of Appeal followed Maguire in its 2001 decision in Techform, supra. In that case the employee signed a technology agreement regarding the ownership of inventions. The evidence was that if he had not signed the agreement the employer would have terminated his contract on 60 days' notice (the contractual notice period). After he signed the agreement the employee was retained for a further four years.
In holding that there was consideration for the agreement, the court, at para. 24, referred with approval to an earlier decision of the British Columbia Court of Appeal:

In Watson [v. Moore Corp. (1996), 134 D.L.R. (4th) 252], McEachern CJBC said that continued employment without more could not serve as consideration for an amendment to the employment contract that was adverse to the employee. That is consistent with the majority judgment in Maguire where central to the finding of consideration was not just the continued employment but the continued forbearing of the employer from exercising its contractual right to dismiss on one month's notice. It is also consistent with the principle fundamental to consideration in the context of an employment contract amendment --- that in return for the new promise received by the employer something must pass to the employee, beyond that to which the employee is entitled under the original contract. Continued employment represents nothing more of value flowing to the employee than under the original contract.

The Ontario Court of Appeal explained its decision in Techform in the more recent decision of Hobbs v. TDI Canada Ltd., supra. In that case, the trial court had followed Maguire and Techform in concluding that there was consideration for an amendment to the employment agreement in the form of the employee's continued employment. The Court of Appeal held that the trial judge erred in relying on those decisions, and that the governing authority in the circumstances was an earlier Ontario Court of Appeal decision: Francis v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, supra.

In summary, while blanket restraints on the freedom to compete are usually held to be unenforceable, the courts have clearly afforded reasonable protection to the confidential information and trade connections of employers. The courts will be more likely to enforce a restrictive covenant where a former employee was intimately acquainted with and had specific knowledge concerning the needs of the former employer's customers.[38]
